awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Multifaceted Approach for Manipulation and Investigation of Quantum Phases and Phase Transitions in Prototypical 2-D Metallic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Explanation: Commonly, materials undergo phase transitions due to change in temperature. A typical example is the transformation of water into ice at zero degrees Celsius. There are also examples of phase transitions, which are controlled solely by non-thermal parameters such as pressure, magnetic field, and compositional disorder. A complete characterization of the key principles behind quantum phase transitions (QPTs) is yet to be accomplished in two-dimensional (2-D) metallic systems, which is believed to be crucial to the realization of intriguing behaviors in various materials of fundamental interest and potential technological import such as cuprate and pnictide high temperature superconductors, ruthenates and heavy fermions. This research project aims at fundamental studies of QPTs in model systems by incorporating a set of complementary experimental techniques. In accordance to its strong commitment to the development of world-class science, technology, engineering and mathematics workforce in the country, this project, in addition to supporting the PhD studies of a graduate student, provides hands-on, research-based, education to undergraduate students at an early stage and local high school students through summer internship. The synergy fostered by this project's integration of education into research is also anticipated to accomplish an important task: preparing the next generation of scientists in the field of synchrotron-based research in the United States. Further education and outreach endeavors of this project comprise development of web based educational materials pertaining to advanced materials characterization techniques for non-experts and broader dissemination of the research activities of the PI's group through lecture-demonstrations, targeted at local non-scientific audiences.

Technical Description: Comprehensive experimental investigations of quantum phase transitions (QPTs) in the phase diagrams of two-dimensional (2-D) metallic systems, in general, are rather intricate. This is mostly because the subtle interplay of competing interactions in these systems often shrouds the relevant quantum critical points stymieing direct experimental access to their quantum criticality. In order to address this issue, this research project adopts a straightforward approach: (i) finds a simple model system with a well defined ordered state, (ii) continuously tunes critical temperature of this state to zero by changing certain non-thermal parameter, and (iii) directly measures changes in various physical properties along with the pertinent order parameter through the quantum critical point. The systems of interest for the current studies are a set of layered transition metal dichalcogenides, namely 2H-NbSe2, 2H-TaS2 and 2H-TaSe2, which possess simple crystal and electronic structures. Each of these compounds exhibits a well defined phase transition via the formation of waves in space with alternating regions of higher and lower density of charges, known as a charge density wave (CDW). Moreover, their CDW transition temperatures can continuously be tuned to zero through various non-thermal processes. In the first avenue of research, CDW orders of these compounds are to be melted quantum mechanically via methodical introduction of electronic and structural disorders in single crystal samples of these materials. In the second line of research, the thickness of single crystal samples are to be gradually diminished transforming them eventually into few- to single-layer thick crystals. Using a combination of Angle Resolved Photoemission Spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and electrical resistivity measurements, critical insights into quantum criticality and quantum phase transitions in 2-D systems are to be attained by (a) unveiling evolution of structural, electrical and electronic properties of these materials along with their CDW order parameters through quantum critical points in temperature-disorder phase diagram, and (b) investigating the impact of quantum confinement on CDW instability and phase transition in few- to single-layer thick samples.  In this context, exact theoretical treatment of quantum criticality in metals is highly challenging because one needs to take into account both single particle excitations and order parameter fluctuations in the same footing. The proposed integration of structural, spectroscopic and transport probes in this project provides a unique opportunity to do so experimentally. Furthermore, this project provides a well-defined methodology to investigate the role of complex disorders on electronic and structural properties of a physical system. This is at the heart of developing materials, which exhibit strongly enhanced responses to external stimuli, useful in energy as well as in device applications.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we studied quantum phases and phase transitions in quasi two-dimensional systems. Here, we briefly describe the intellectual merit and the broader impact of the activities pursued in this project.

Intellectual Merit: In the following paragraphs, we briefly highlight our main discoveries.

(i) Band convergence driven  high thermopower in PbX (X=Te,Se,S): Despite detailed investigations, the mechanism of high thermoelectric efficiency, and the interconnection between temperature evolution of thermopower and electronic structure remain outstanding in PbX, premier thermoelectric materials. Our angle resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) data evidenced for the light hole upper valence bands and heavy hole lower valence bands in these materials (Fig. 1) (EPL 117, 27006 (2017)). An unusual temperature-dependent relative movement (Fig. 2) between these bands leads to a monotonic decrease in the band gap with increasing temperature, which is referred as band convergence. Direct observation of band convergence supports its suggested role behind high thermopower of PbX at elevated temperatures.

(ii) Pseudogap, anisotropic electron-phonon coupling and orbital selectivity underlying charge density wave (CDW) instability in transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs): The mechanism of CDW orders in TMDs such as 2H-NbSe2 and 2H-TaS2 is an intriguing puzzle. Like in cuprate high temperature superconductors (HTSCs), these materials also host pseudogap phase, but there is a qualitative difference between them (Fig. 3). In one class of models, strong and anisotropic electron-phonon coupling together with the orbital selectivity of the electronic states at the Fermi level are central to the CDW instability in TMDs. Detecting momentum anisotropy of electron-boson coupling is, however, not straightforward. Using ARPES measurements, we found pronounced many-body renormalizations, caused by electron-phonon interactions, in 2H-TaS2. The electron?phonon coupling parameter is momentum-dependent (Fig. 4), and the CDW ordering vector doesn?t match with any of the Fermi surface nesting vectors. Collectively, these observations establish that the CDW transition in 2H-TaS2 is not same as the Peierls ordering transition, rather this transition is triggered by strong electron?phonon coupling including its momentum anisotropy. These results lead to the following publications: PRB 96, 125103 (2017); PRB 99, 245144 (2019); J. Mater. Chem. C 5, 11310 (2017) and Proceedings of SPIE 10357, UNSP 103570Q (2017).

(iii) Adequacy of magnetic fluctuations to enable  high transition temperatures (Tcs) in cuprate HTSCs: The pairing mechanism in cuprate HTSCs is a much debated topic. In some theoretical scenarios, spin fluctuations mediate the Cooper pairing. It is, however, not quite clear whether spin fluctuations alone can adequately take into account of high Tcs in the cuprates. To test these models, we constructed the single-loop spin-fluctuation-mediated pairing interaction assuming Cooper pairing driven solely by spin fluctuations, and use it to compute the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues of the Bethe-Salpeter equation in the particle-particle channel for multiple Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8+δ (BI2212) HTSC samples. With decreasing temperature, the leading eigenvalue increases upon approaching Tc, reaching a value of approximately 1 at the Tc at each measured doping value, indicating a potential superconducting transition with d-wave eigenfunctions. This suggests that spin fluctuations can adequately account for Tc and, consequently, mediate pairing in the cuprate HTSCs. Publications based on these results are: Nature Communications 7, 11875 (2016) & Commun Phys 5, 45 (2022). A manuscript following up these works is currently being finalized, which examines separately the temperature dependence of the magnetic pairing interaction and the pairing kernel in the pseudogap regime of the BI2212 samples.

Broader Impact:

This project has been beneficial to the participating graduate, masters (MS), undergraduate (UG) students for their trainings and professional developments in terms of offering them solid research-oriented education. Two  graduate students were supported by this grant. Kapila Wijayaratne, one of the graduate students, gained expertise  in state-of-the-art ARPES technique by using lab-based and synchrotron-based instruments.  Recently, he joined University of Peradeniya, one of the premier universities in Srilanka, as a faculty member. This grant also enabled research projects for six UG and one Masters (MS) student. International UG student Abhishek Pal from India spent one semester working on this project in our lab.  After finishing his thesis project in our lab, UG student Andrew Coffee is currently working as an Electrical Engineer at the Naval Research Lab. UG students Andreas Butler and Vis Karlapati went to Caltech and UCSD, respectively for their graduate studies in physics. MS student Anchit Arora worked briefly on this project and has started his graduate studies at the University of Vurginia physics department.

Before the COVID pandemic, the PI arranged tours for the UG students to the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Lab. During these tours, the students get the opportunity to visit the synchrotron beamlines, interact with the scientists at APS and Materials Science Division. These meetings have been helpful for the UG students to find internship opportunities at Argonne.
